messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Nihiki design ...
messages.msgSnippet: All- Hiki is the counter for cloth. fine bolts of silk cloth were given as presents. I am begining to think this is two bolts of cloth BUT. The Japanese
messages.messageBody:
All-
Hiki is the counter for cloth. fine bolts
of silk cloth were given as presents. I am
begining to think this is two bolts of cloth BUT.
The Japanese website gives a different kanji (see
below) So I sent them an email to see what they
say it means...
-t

à¯Ç vsÅ@ïD

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Nihiki design ...
messages.msgSnippet: John, I pictured the ji-sukashi version, but this type in negative openwork with the elongated rectangles is often interpreted as a battle banners or as
messages.messageBody:
John,
I pictured the ji-sukashi version, but this type in negative openwork with the elongated rectangles is often interpreted as a battle banners or as tanzaku "poem cards." The square format writing card is called shikishi, but that is a long stretch from nihiki.

Jim

Tom
I found the description on an advertisement for a tsuba on Tokugawa
Art. This has two measuring boxes, one either side of the seppa-dai,
and is described as 'nihiki design'.

http://www.sanmei.com/shop_e/enter.html

Regards, John L.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Nihiki design ...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi John, I am not familiar with the term hiki, and will have to look it up, but I am pretty sure the ni part is two and the hiki part refers to the very
messages.messageBody:
Hi John,

I am not familiar with the term "hiki," and will have to look it up, but I
am pretty sure the "ni" part is two and the "hiki" part refers to the very
large hitsu-ana.

Gordon

simularities and I thought the Higo fitted the school better than
Akasaka in the end. I probably would guess it to be mid Edo or there
abouts, maybe a bit later ???,

Cheerrs

Rich

messages.messageBody:
Rich,
Based on what I could see in the photo at the time that was my thought as well. Not an early one though. I think that Eckhard Kremers' book has a similar example.

Jim



http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/akasaka_tadatoki_tea.jpg

Ok, I have labelled this Akasaka but..... I am strongly starting to
think it could be Higo Nishigaki, Jim G, you said to have a good look as
it may well be something else ( other than Akasaka ) and I did. I knew
right off it didn't have the normal Akasaka mimi, and the edges are just
a little soft for the usual seen in akasaka, and it is probably just a
bit too thin in the mimi but that does not automatically rule it out,
the depth of the tsuba is also thin for Akasaka but again.......

I think if not Akasaka then Higo is a good call ????? and maybe in
particular, Higo Nishigaki.

Thought's, right or wrong ?????

Rich

messages.subject: Re: Nihiki design ...
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Jim Thank you for your helpful suggestions - sadly I do not have the kanji for nihiki.  The most appropriate translation for nihiki design would perhaps
messages.messageBody:
Dear Jim
Thank you for your helpful suggestions - sadly I do not have the
kanji for nihiki. The most appropriate translation for 'nihiki
design' would perhaps be 'two thingys design'!
Regards, John L.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nihiki design ...
messages.msgSnippet: John, If I am picturing it correctly, the rectangular openings are usually interpreted as representing measuring boxes (masu).  The design with two boxes is
messages.messageBody:
John,
If I am picturing it correctly, the rectangular openings are usually interpreted as representing measuring boxes (masu). The design with two boxes is called sayu-masu (left and right boxes).

My Japanese language skills are minimal, but I only know of nihiki as the "counting word" used for two small animals. I asked my shodo teacher (first native speaker I remembered to ask) if she could think of any other meaning for nihiki or a way that it might relate to that motif, but no luck.

Do you know what the kanji are for that nihiki?

It just occurred to me to try a google image search on nihiki. Most hits are photos of pairs of dogs, cats, rabbits, etc., but interestingly this jpg http://www005.upp.so-net.ne.jp/minbun/news/news21/nihiki.jpg
of a kimono turned up. Kimono sleeves are normally called sode as far as I know, but the two rectangular sleeves would fit the two rectangle motif. The nihiki 二引 in the caption I think refers to the kind of garment, but I don't know the meaning. It's probably a red herring. The source page is here:

http://www005.upp.so-net.ne.jp/minbun/news/news21/news21.html

Oddly on the same page I noticed this
http://www005.upp.so-net.ne.jp/minbun/news/news21/kodougu.jpg
which looks like a large harvesting knife in shirasaya with a koshirae. I've seen plenty of bamboo splitting knives with blades like that, but not with a habaki or koshirae. Something for a performance? Does anyone know?

Jim



Dear Members

Can anybody please tell me what is meant by the term 'nihiki design'?
It appears to refer to a tsuba design incorporating two rectangular
openings, one on each side of the seppa-dai, but I have never been
able to identify what, if anything, these represent.

Regards, John L.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re:
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Richard, Wow, that is interesting what they used to do it.  Someone suggested something simular on one of my coin lists to repatinate the coins, and they
messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard,
Wow, that is interesting what they used to do it. Someone suggested
something simular on one of my coin lists to repatinate the coins, and
they suggested using horse or cow dung and something like pee too. I
don't know if they were serious or not, but I don't think anyone tryed
it. :-D

Kim

>chemical replacements for things like dung these days.

>>Kim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re:
messages.msgSnippet: Patina on tsuba is placed on at manufacture and in the old days, included a mixture of red clay, straw, rat dung, sulphur, gunpowder,salt and other things.
messages.messageBody:
Patina on tsuba is placed on at manufacture and in the old days,
included a mixture of red clay, straw, rat dung, sulphur, gunpowder,salt
and other things. Many layers and applications are applied. It's a time
consuming thing. These are of course old recipes and they may have
chemical replacements for things like dung these days.

Rich

> just wondering if it is the same in regards to the Swords. I work with
> Greek (earlier times and Imperial), Roman (Republican, Provincial,
> Imperial) and Byzantine cup coins. Most what we are having to deal with
> is Bronze, but we do get Silver or Silvered coins and some copper.
>
> Kim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re:
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you Richard, I was just wondering, as I m on a couple of Ancient Coin lists and I also use electrolysis to clean coins, and it is suppose to work
messages.messageBody:
Thank you Richard, I was just wondering, as I'm on a couple of Ancient
Coin lists and I also use electrolysis to clean coins, and it is suppose
to work backwards to repatinate the coin (I've never done this). I was
just wondering if it is the same in regards to the Swords. I work with
Greek (earlier times and Imperial), Roman (Republican, Provincial,
Imperial) and Byzantine cup coins. Most what we are having to deal with
is Bronze, but we do get Silver or Silvered coins and some copper.

Kim

Richard Turner wrote:

>Hi Kim, I don't think anyone will answer that, an inherently dangerous
>question that could only lead to tears. You will be told 99.9% of the
>time, it is best left to the experts.
>
>So the answer would be, We DON'T repatinate parts of our swords, we send
>them to polishers and they do it.
>
>cheers
>
>Rich Turner

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re:
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Kim, I don t think anyone will answer that, an inherently dangerous question that could only lead to tears. You will be told 99.9% of the time, it is best
messages.messageBody:
Hi Kim, I don't think anyone will answer that, an inherently dangerous
question that could only lead to tears. You will be told 99.9% of the
time, it is best left to the experts.

So the answer would be, We DON'T repatinate parts of our swords, we send
them to polishers and they do it.

cheers

Rich Turner

Kim Ghobrial wrote:

> Hi All,
> No one responded to my questions. Can someone please tell me how you
> guys repatinate your parts of the swords? Also, what is recipe for
> doing it?
>
> Sincerely,
> Kim
>

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/akasaka_tadatoki_tea.jpg

Ok, I have labelled this Akasaka but..... I am strongly starting to
think it could be Higo Nishigaki, Jim G, you said to have a good look as
it may well be something else ( other than Akasaka ) and I did. I knew
right off it didn't have the normal Akasaka mimi, and the edges are just
a little soft for the usual seen in akasaka, and it is probably just a
bit too thin in the mimi but that does not automatically rule it out,

particular, Higo Nishigaki.

Rich

messages.subject: Nihiki design ...
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Members Can anybody please tell me what is meant by the term nihiki design ? It appears to refer to a tsuba design incorporating two rectangular
messages.messageBody:
Dear Members

Can anybody please tell me what is meant by the term 'nihiki design'?
It appears to refer to a tsuba design incorporating two rectangular
openings, one on each side of the seppa-dai, but I have never been
able to identify what, if anything, these represent.

Regards, John L.
